FrequentlyOccasionally during the
very dry seasons which
succeed our winter and
preceede our rains a dry
hot ˄ wind blows over the
Desert from North to South
It feels somewhat as if
coming from an oven
and seldom blows
longer at a time than three
days together: It resembles in its
effects the Harmattan for
of the North of
Africa for ^ it coames loaded aboutat

305 years ago loaded

sand - The sand no
longer appears
but it is so
devoid of
moisture that And it causes the
wood of the best seasoned
English boxes & furniture
to shrink so much that
every article not made
in the country becomes
warped - The verls of
ramrods made in England
become loose and on
returning fto Europe fasten
again - This wind is so
strongly electric that
a bunch of ˄ ostrich feathers held
in it a few seconds
against it become as strongly
charged electrified as they would
do if attached to in a powerful electrical
machine, and clasp
256 296
the advancing hand aswith

experiment were performed

On shewingshowing this phenomenon

On the 31st DecrDecember 1852 we reached
the town of Sechele called
from the part of the range
on which it is situated
Litubaruba - I never
- saw the Bakwains looking
so haggard and lean
as now - Most of the
cattle had been swept away
together with about 80
fine draught oxen and
much provision left in charge
by two officers Captains
Codrington and Webb to
serve ˄ for their return journey
South - Theyse ^ officers found the
skeletons of the Bakwains
where they expected to find
their goods - All the corn,
clothing, and furniture
of the people had been
consumed in the flames
which the Boers had
forced the subject tribes
to apply to the town
during the fight to the So they were
now literally starving -

Sechele had given orders
to his people not to
commit any act of
revenge pending his
visit to the queenQueen ˄ of England - but
some of the young men
ventured to go to a party
of Boers returning from
259 5 299
hunting and as the Boers
became terrified and
ran off they brought
their waggon to Litubaruba
This seems to have given
the main body an idea
that he^ the Bakwains meant to begin
a guerilla war upon
them - This Caffre war
was however only in
embryo and not near
that stage of [development
93 which we by coming
after the Boers have
unwisely inherited, when
the native finds the hide
and seed seek system
most successful - The
Boers in alarm sent
to ask for peace! I being
present heard the condition
"Sechele's children must
be given up" - I never
saw men so completely
and unconsciously in
a trap as these four Boers
were - Strong parties of
armed Bakwains occupied
every pass in the hills &
gorges around and had
they not promised much
more than they intended
or did perform that sunday
would have been their
last
260 300
Mr Peit ScholzScholz the commandant
had appropriated the children
of Sechele to be his own
domestic slaves - I was
present when one little
boy Khari son of
Sechele was returned to his
mother Ma-balerileng - The
X child had been allowed

there were three large
unbound ^ open sores on different

The Bechuanas are universally much
attached to children - A little child toddling
near a party of men eating is sure
to get a handful of the food - This
love of children may depend inin a great
partmeasure on the patriarchal system under which
they dwell - Every little stranger is an
increase of value influence to the whole community
and is duly reported to the chief - boys
being more esteemed welcome than girls - The
parents take the name of the child & often address
their children as Ma or Ra - (mother & father)
Our eldest boy being named Robert Mrs
L -Livingstone was after his birth always addressed
as Marobert - instead of Mary her maiden
name -

I have examined several cases in
which a grandmother has taken upon herself
to suckle a grandchild - Masina of Kuruman
had no children after the birth of her ^ daughter Sina
and had no milk after Sina was weaned
which usually is deferred till the child is
two or three years old - Sina married
when she was 17 or 18 and had twins
Masina ^ after at least 15 yearsyears' interval took possession of one of
them applied it to her breast and milk
followed so that she was able to nursed
the child ^ Entirelyentirely - On examination it seemed like omit
other human milk only perhaps a little
more bluish than ordinary - She was at
this time at least 40 years of age -
I have witnessed several other cases
analogous to this - A grandmother left
at home with a young child ^ frequently applies
it to her own shrivelled breast ^

I have seen mere infants

and the only thing which

and slave

The diseases known
among the Bakwains
are remarkably few -
There is no consumption, nor
scrofula and insanity and
hydrocephalus are rare -
Cancer and cholera are
quite unknown - Smallpox
and measles came through
the country about twenty
years ago but t and com-
mitted great ravages
but though the former was
has since broken out ^ on the coast repeatedly
neither disease has they never travelled inland
since - For small pox
the natives they employed in some
parts inoculation with
in the forehead with the
263 303
droppings of a bull - In
other parts they employed
the matter of the small-
pox itself and in one
village they seem to have
selected a virulent case
for the matter used in
the operation for nearly
all the village was
swept off by the disease
in a malignant confluent
form - Where the idea
came from I cannot
concieveconceive - It was practised
by the Bakwains at a time
when they had no intercourse
direct or indirect with
the Southern missionaries - They all adopt
readily the plan
of vaccine virus
when it is
brought within
their reach

Syphilis is unknown
also - I have seen cases
in which it had been
imparted and appeared in
the secondary form ^ but it died
out without the aid of
medicine - And the Bang-
-waketze who got the
mildest form of it from
a tribe of Damaras near
the West Coast lost it
when they came into their
own land South West
of Kolobeng - It seems
incapable of permanence
in any form in persons
264 10304
of pure African blood anywhere
in the centre of the country,
In persons of mixed
blood it is otherwise and
the virulence of the secondary
symptoms seemed to be
in all the cases that came
under my care - in exact
proportion to the greater
or less amount of European
blood in the patient -
Among the Corannas and
Griquas of mixed breed
it produces the same
ravages as in Europe -
Among half blood Portuguese
it is equally frightful
in its inroads on the
system but in the pure
Negro of the central parts
it is quite incapable of
permanence - Among the
Barotse I found a disease
called Manassah which
closely resembles ^ that of the "foeda
mulier", of history -

Equally unknown
is stone in the bladder
and gravel - I never met
with a case though the waters
are often ^ so strongly impregnated
with sulphate of lime that
265 305
kettles quickly become
incrusted internally with
the salt - And some of
my patients who were
troubled with indigestion
believed that their stomachs
? had got into the same
condition - This freedom
from calculi seems would
appear to be remarkable
in the ^ negro race even in the
Un United States for seldom
indeed have the fam most
famed Lithotomists there
operated on a negro -

The diseases most
prevalent ^ are the following -- pneumonia,
produced by sudden
changes in temperature --
and other inflammations
as of the bowels, stomach
and pleura Rheumatism
disease of the
heart - but
these become
rare as the
people adopt
the European
dress - - Various
forms of indigestion
and ophthalmia - Hooping
cough comes frequently
and every year the period
preceding the rains
is marked by some
sort of epidemic - Sometimes
it is general ophthalmia
resembling closely the Egyptian
AtIn another year it is
a kind of Diarrhoea which
266 306
which nothing will cure
untilluntil there is a fall of
QuQuery anything rain and anything or nothing
acts as a charm after
that - One year the epidemic
period was was
^ marked by a disease
which looked like pneumonia
but had the peculiar symptom
strongly developed of
great pain in the 7th
cervical process - Many
persons died of it ^ after being in a comatose
state for many hours
or days before their
decease - No inspection
of the body being ever
allowed and the place
of sepulture being carefully
concealed I had to rest
satisfied with conjecture
Frequently the Bakwains
burned their dead in
the huts where they died
for fear lest the witches
(Baloi) should disinter
their friends and use
some parts of the body
in their fiendish arts -
Scarcely did the is the
breath out of the body
when than the unfortunate
patient is hurried away
to be buried - An anteatersanteater's
hole is often selected in
267 307
order to save the trouble of digging
a grave - On two occasions
while I was there, this hasty burial led to
the return home again
of the man who had been
buried alive, to his
afrightedaffrighted relatives

The doctors cup on the
temples and apply the
pungent smoke of certain roots to the eyes
in ophthalmia - The
patient at the same time
taking strong draughts of
it up his nostrils - We
found the solution of nitrate
of silver * * 2 or 3 grams
to the ounce
of rain water answer
the same end so much
more effectually that
every morning crowds
numbers ^ of patients crowded round
our house for the collyrium
It is a good preventative
of an acute attack
when poured in to the eyes
as soon as the pain
begins and might prove
valuable for travellers
The cupping glass is performed
by the horn of a goat or
antelope having a smalllittle
hole pierced in the small
end - In some cases a
small piece of wax is
attached and a temporary
hole made through it to
268 308
in the horn - When the air is
well withdrawn by keeping
the touching the orifice at
every inspiration with the
point of the tongue - The
wax is at last bittenpressed with
the teeth and the orifice ob-
literated closed up so as to leave a
vacuum for the blood
to flow from the already
scarified parts - The edges of
the horn applied to the surface are
wetted and cupping is well
performed though the doctor
occasionally by separating
the fibrinefibrin from the blood
in the basin of water by
his side and exhibiting it
pretends that he has extracted

He can then explain the
rationale of the cure by his
own art and the ocular
demonstration given is well
appreciated -

Those doctors who have
inherited theis profession as an heirloom
from their fathers & grandfathers ^ generally possess some
valuable knowledge the
result of long and close
observation - but if a man
cannot say the medical art
is in his family he may
be considered a quack. With
269 309
the others I always remained
on the best of terms by always
refraining from appearing
to doubt their skill in the
presence of their patients
x Aside, any explanation was
thankfully recievedreceived ^ by them and
wrong treatment changed into
something more more reasonable with cordial
good will if no one but
the doctor & myself heard
& myself were present theat the conversation - English
medicines were eagerly
asked for & accepted by all - And we
always found medical knowledge
an important aid in
convincing the people that
we were really anxious
for their welfare - We cannot
accuse them of ingratitude
^ in fact Wewe shall We remember the kindness of
the Bakwains to us as long
as we live -

270 310
The surgical knowledge of
the native doctors is rather
at a low ebb - No one ever
attempted to remove a tumour
except by external applications
Those with which they are
chiefly troubled are fatty &
fibrous tumours - and as
they all have the vis medicatrix
naturae in remarkable
activity I safely removed
an immense number -
In illustration of their want
of surgical knowledge it
may be mentioned that
a man having a tumour
as large as a childschild's head
- which being situated on
the nape of his neck
prevented himhis walking
straight - applied to his chief
to get some famous strange
doctor from the East coast
to cure him - They attempted
to dissolve it by kindling
on it a little fire ^ on it made of a few
small little pieces of medicinal
roots - When I removed it
for him and he always walked with his
head much more erect
than he needed to do ever
afterwards - Both men &
women submit to an
operation without wincing
or any of that shouting
271 311
which caused young students
to faint in the operating
theatre before the introduction
of chloroform - - The women
pride themselves on their
ability to bear pain - A
mother will address her child
little girl from whose foot a thorn
is to be extracted by - "Now
Ma you are a woman - A
woman does not cry" - A
man too scorns to shed tears
When we were passing one of
the deep wells in the Kalahari
a boy the only son of an
aged father had been drowned
in it while playing on
its brink - When all hope
was gone ^ the father he uttered an
exceedingly great & bitter cry
It was sorrow without
hope, This was the only
instance I ever met with
of a man weeping in
this country -

Their ideas on obstetrics
are equally uninoperative - and
the idea of a ^ medical man going near
a woman at her confinement a lady in the straw appeared
to them more out of placeout of place than a
female medical student
appears to us in a male
dissecting room - A case of
twins however happening
272 312
and all the ointments of all
the doctors of the town proving
utterly inefficient incompetentinsufficient to effect
a delivery the relief which a few
seconds of English art
afforded the prejudice at
vanished at once - As it would
have been out of the question
for me ^ to have entered upon this branch
of the profession as indeed
it would be inexpedient improper for
any medical man to devote
himself exclusively in a
thinly peopled country to the
practice of medicine I there-
after reserved myself for the
difficult cases only and
had the satisfaction of often
conferring great benefits
on poor women in their
hour of sorrow - The poor
creatures are often leftplaced in a little hut
built for the purpose ^ and are left without
any assistance whatever
and the numbers of umbilical
herniae which are met with
is very greatquite astonishing in consequence
The women They suffer less ^ ^ at their confinements ^ than ^ is the case in
civilized countries; perhaps
from ^ their treating it not as a
disease but as an operation
of nature requiring no change
of diet except a feast of meat
and abundance of fresh air -
273 313
The husband on these occasions
being bound to slaughter anfor his
lady an ox or a goat or sheep according
to his means - No further
QuQuery omit intercourse is supposed to take

My knowledge of
obstetrics procured for me
a great fame in a line
toin which I could lay no
claim ^ to merit - A woman came
from the a distance of 100 miles
for relief in a complaint
which seemed to have
baffled the native doctors
a complete cure was the
result - Soon after she
returned to her husband she
concievedconceived and bore a son
Her husband having
previously reproached her
for being barren she sent
me a handsome present
and proclaimed all over
the country that I possessed
thea medicine for the cure
of sterility - The consequence
was ^ that I was pestered with
applications from husbands
and wives all over the
country - Some came upwards
of 200 miles to purchase
the great boon and it was
in vain ^ for me to explain ^ that I could
only cure the disease of
274 20314
the other case - The more I
denied they higher their offers
became - They would give
any money for the "child
medicine" and it was really
heart rending to hear the
earnest entreaty and see
the tearful eye which spoke
the intense desire - "I am getting
old, you see gray hairs here
and there on my head, and
I have no child, you know
how Bechuana husbands
cast their old wives away
What can I do, I have no
child to bring water to me
when I am sick" &c -

The whole of the country
adjacent to the Desert from
Kuruman to Kolobeng
or Litubaruba and beyond
up to the Latitude of
Lake Ngami is remarkable
for its great salubrity of
climate - Not only the natives
but Europeans whose
constitutions have been im-
-paired by an Indian climate
find the tract of country
indicated not subject both healthy
and but restorative - The health
and longevity of the missionaries
275 315
hasve been always fair, though
mission work is not
very conducive to either
elsewhere - Cases have
been known in which
patients have come from
the coast with a complaints
closely ^ simulatingresembling if ^ it they were not
actually ^ those of consumption,;
and they have recovered
by the influence of the
climate alone - One of these
a woman I examined
and found ovarian
tumour, as if the tuberculous
matter had had been
removed from the lungs
& deposited in another organ there - She
is still aliveng while had
she with that same disease
remained near the coast
it would speedily ^ have been as
fatal to her as it is to
the Hottentots - It must
always bee borne in mind
that the climate near the
coast from which we
recievedreceived sosuch very favourable
reports of the health of the
British troops is actually
inferior to that of any
part not subjected to
the influence of sea air
I have never seen the
276 316
the beneficial effects of the
inland climate on ^ persons of ^ shattered
constitutions nor and heard
their loudhigh praises of the
benefit they have derived
from travelling without
wishing that its bracing
effects should become
more extensively known ^
in England ^ N No one who has
visited the region I have
above mentioned fails
to remember thewith pleasure
of the wild healthful gipseygypsy
life of waggon travelling A considerable
proportion of
animal diet
seems requisite
here - IndependantIndependent
of the want of
salt we required
meat in as large
quantity daily
as we do in
England and
no bad effects
follow ^ the free
use of flesh
in the way of
biliousness as
in other hot
climates - A
vegetabevegetable diet
causes acidity & heartburn
Mr OswelOswell declares this
climate farmuch superior
to that of Peru as far as
pleasure is concerned
and but for the impossibility
of my giving accurate
scientific data from
want of instruments to
the medical world and
the expense of such a trip
being so high I would
have no hesitation
to recommend the borders
of the Kalahari desert
as admirably suited for
all patients having
pulmonary complaints
It is the complete antipodes
to our cold damp English
277 317
climate - The winter is perfectly
dry - and as not a drop of
rain falls during that
period - vizvidelicet from the beginning
of May to the end of August
damp and cold are never
combined - However hot
the day wasmay have been
at Kolobeng and the thermometer
sometimes rose previous
to a fall of rain up to 96°
in the coolest part of our
house yet it never has
that steamy feeling nor
those debilitating effects
so well known in India
In the evenings the air
becomes deliciously cool
and a pleasant refreshing
night follows the hottest
day - The greatest heat
ever felt is not so oppressive
as it is when there is much
humidity in the air and
the great evaporation
consequent on a fall of
rain makes the raining
season the most agreableagreeable
for travelling - Nothing can
exceed the delicious balmy
feeling of the evenings &
mornings aftduring the whole
year - You can wish for
neither an increase of
cold nor heat - It is perfect
278 24318
and you can sit out at night till
midnight ^twelve ^ without ever thinking
